question.text: At the end of the G<sub>2</sub> phase, the number of chromosomes and the amount of <math><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> in a diploid cell, respectively, is

solution.text: If a cell at <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></math> phase has <math><mn>2</mn><mi>n</mi></math> chromosome and <math><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A,</mi></math> then during <math><mi>S </mi><mi>p</mi><mi>h</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>e,</mi></math> <math><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> replication occurs but chromosome number remains unchanged. As a result, chromosome number remains <math><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></math> but the quantity of <math><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> becomes <math><mn>4</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>.
